timeline.subject: Jannon femme d'Arnould Jacquel
timeline.details: Jannon met Jacotte at Seuche, became ill immediately after returning home

timeline.subject: Jacotte Colin
timeline.details: Nicolas Pironel, prévôt d'Arches, took testimony from Jannon about her illness

timeline.subject: Demengeon Romary (husband)
timeline.details: Husband came before Prévôt to demand reparation or proof of charge

timeline.subject: Jacotte Colin
timeline.details: Procureur General des Vosges orders investigation of Jacotte

timeline.subject: Jacotte Colin
timeline.details: Formal witness depositions begin (20 witnesses total)

timeline.subject: Jacotte Colin
timeline.details: PG des Vosges asks for arrest and interrogation

timeline.subject: Jacotte Colin
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture; confessed after being given water

timeline.subject: Jacotte Colin
timeline.details: Repeated confessions, admitted to more animal killings

timeline.subject: Jacotte Colin
timeline.details: Procureur General des Vosges asks for death sentence

timeline.subject: Jacotte Colin
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence

accomplices_named.name: Collette femme Jean Jacot Michel (also Jean Paret)
accomplices_named.context: Took Jacotte to sabbat 9 or 10 years before; told her many witches came from Pont des Fayes

prior_accusations.context: Accused Jacotte 8 years before (around 1586), but voluntarily withdrew accusation; Jacotte was discharged

notable_quotes.speaker: Jannon femme d'Arnould Jacquel
notable_quotes.french: Que toutesfois ce qu'elle en a dict presentement n'est pour s'en plaindre, ains en donner advertissement seulement; et que sy ladite Jacotte la vouloit guerir, elle luy pardonneroit, et n'en parleroit jamais.
notable_quotes.english: However what she has said presently is not to complain, but only to give warning; and that if said Jacotte would cure her, she would pardon her, and never speak of it again.
notable_quotes.context: Initial testimony about her illness attributed to Jacotte

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacotte Colin (to Marion widow)
notable_quotes.french: Ne te veux tu pas marier affin que je mange de tes nopces
notable_quotes.english: Don't you want to marry so that I may eat at your wedding feast
notable_quotes.context: Said to Claudon at mill while touching him on shoulders; he died 6 years before trial

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Romary (husband's voice overheard)
notable_quotes.french: Je void bien que quant j'auray tant fait de a mes bons amys, il t'en faudra aller au diable.
notable_quotes.english: I see well that when I have done so much for my good friends, you will have to go to the devil.

notable_quotes.speaker: Margueritte (witness 9) quoting Jacotte
notable_quotes.english: that he would not come there much more
notable_quotes.context: Threat to father about honey bees; he died 4-5 months later

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Estienne Raon quoting Jacotte
notable_quotes.french: tu n'ay garde de par le Diable
notable_quotes.english: you need not fear by the Devil
notable_quotes.context: Response when witness said he would blame her if he fell ill

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacotte Colin (to Marion witness 5)
notable_quotes.french: a menty comme une meschante femme et faulse dixmeresse, qu'elle se damne perpetuellement et qu'elle n'en verra en sa vie la face de Dieu
notable_quotes.english: has lied like a wicked woman and false tithe-collector, that she damns herself perpetually and that she will never in her life see the face of God

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacotte Colin (to Cury Jacot Michel)
notable_quotes.french: que c'est un meschant usurier, mangeur et rongeur de peuple et que les fiebvres quartaines luy puissent relier le coeur en son ventre
notable_quotes.english: that he is a wicked usurer, eater and gnawer of people and that quartan fevers may bind his heart in his belly

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacotte Colin (end of confrontations)
notable_quotes.french: que le Diable les emporte tous; et en puisse avoir l'ame et la chair
notable_quotes.english: may the Devil take them all; and may he have their soul and flesh

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacotte Colin (under torture)
notable_quotes.english: I will speak your wine well
notable_quotes.context: Said to Prévôt after being given water during torture, before starting confession

notable_quotes.speaker: Demengeon Romary (husband)
notable_quotes.french: que sy sadite femme y scavoit quelque chose qu'elle la gueriroit
notable_quotes.english: that if his said wife knew something about it she would cure her
notable_quotes.context: Husband begging pardon for Jacotte to cure Jannon

relationships.evidence_text: daughter of the late Humbert Jannol of Seuch
had a daughter and two sons, aged 12, 10, and 5
had a daughter and two sons, aged 12, 10, and 5
had a daughter and two sons, aged 12, 10, and 5
Her husband had been married twice before; two daughters by earlier marriage were living in Allemaigne
Marion veuve de Jacot Estiennon Petit Demenge
Blamed her father's death on Jacotte
Mongeotte veuve de George Gillet Pierre Geoffroy
Francoise femme de Pierot Blaise Andre
he had kept company with her husband

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over shared resources (pear tree, passage by meix, payment for guarding cows, ox purchase). Cury Jacot Michel described as 'meschant usurier, mangeur et rongeur de peuple' (wicked usurer, eater and gnawer of people) by Jacotte, and noted as rich with his wife being 'rude aux pauvres gens' (harsh to poor people). Economic tensions evident in community.

prior_legal_disputes.description: Husband demanded reparation for charge against wife by Jannon, or that Jannon be forced to prove accusation (January 14, 1594)
Previous accusation by Collette femme Jean Paret about 8 years before (around 1586), confronted at Arches
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Collette voluntarily withdrew accusation, Jacotte discharged

legal_context.redress_outcome: Husband Demengeon Alix came before Prévôt on January 14, 1594 to demand reparation or proof; this led to formal investigation rather than clearing his wife's name
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: sent back to prison between interrogations

hearsay_chains.content: Jacotte gave 'le mal de mort' to Claudon, son of Jacot Estiennon, who asked for arquebus to shoot her
claimed Jacotte had killed their father
husband said wife was malheureuse and he would leave her
chased by great black beast like bear when driven from house by stepmother
Jacotte's husband said she was 'une malheureuse femme' and would leave her
accusation by Colette femme Jean Paret, then discharged

emotional_state_notes: demanding witnesses be arrested and forced to apologize
started to confess after water torture
thanked God for bringing her back to path of good

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Marion 'a menty comme une meschante femme et faulse dixmeresse, qu'elle se damne perpetuellement et qu'elle n'en verra en sa vie la face de Dieu' - demanded Marion be arrested until she begs pardon; claimed Marion had come to beg at her house several times
Cury Jacot Michel 'a menty cinquante pieds dans le ventre' and 'que c'est un meschant usurier, mangeur et rongeur de peuple et que les fiebvres quartaines luy puissent relier le coeur en son ventre'
To Nicolas Arnould Raon objected 'que quant on va voir un malade, on ne peult moins luy donner ou porter quelque chose' - that when visiting sick person one must bring something
Said if Jean Collusse charged her with death of his wife 'il se damne perpetuellement et mect sadite femme en peine'

extraction_metadata.notes: Rich trial record with 20 witnesses providing detailed testimony. Clear timeline from initial complaint (January 13, 1594) to execution (May 14, 1594). Extensive catalog of alleged harms spanning many years, with multiple patterns: quarrels followed by harm, healing followed by accusation, food/touch as vectors. Strong reputation evidence (20+ years, mother also suspected). Accused showed fierce resistance during confrontations but confessed under torture. Confession included sabbat attendance, devil pact, and admission to killing Marion wife of Cury Jacot Michel. Economic tensions evident throughout (usury accusations, payment disputes, shared resources). Notable that husband initially defended wife but she was still convicted. Trial costs noted as 42 livres.
